events.text:
Welcome aboard!
Your first job in this station is to guard against meteor attacks. 
Those happen fairly often here, so we have some rotating platforms to defend against. 
Now you may ask, why not just have force fields? 
The answer is, we don’t have the budget and we have to use moving platforms instead.
That’s life for you.
...
Anyhow, to describe how it goes:
First we get a report of meteors that are flying towards the station. 
We also get information on the available platforms. 
The task is to set the initial rotation (aka theta) for each platform,
so that meteors crash into platforms and not into the space station.
Before you can operate the platforms you ought to know how the dashboard works.
Buttons before everything else!

You first want to start with the forecast view.
It contains information about the upcoming meteors, as well as platforms you will need to configure.
You can’t defend against what you don’t know, you know.

Moving on, there’s config view which opens up the configuration terminal which lets you change the initial rotation. 
Now you might ask, how to know which angles to use?
First and foremost, brute-force is not the key.
I once tried it. 
Had to be responsible for repairing that hole.
I’d much rather watch paint dry, so it was not worth it. 
...
For that you use a formula and it’s such:
[wave amp=50 freq=2]formula[/wave]
This formula required some trigonometric magic and I’ve added the proof which I’ve written back in the days when we first got the rotating platforms.
I’ll be honest, while I kind of understand how to get there, I’m not certain I would reach this myself
even if I’d be held at gunpoint. 
So don’t worry if you don’t get how, just know that it works.

Also, you don’t even have to know it because we have Collidix – the machinery that does the calculations for us.
Just press the Calculate button...

...and you get the angles and all that’s left is to just take them and insert them in the configuration terminal.
Actually it’s not that easy.
Usually there are 2 platforms and 3 meteors, so that means that at least 1 platform would need to take care of at least 2 meteors.
Either 1 platform takes down 3 meteors or 1 platform takes down 2 and the other one takes down another meteor.
Keep that in mind while picking the right angles!

When you have done your configuration, it’s time to go to the Confirm view and finalize your configuration.
Remember,
you mess up, you clean up.
